posts.text:
I feel like everyone has a manner of themed speech, almost like a leitmotif, that sets them apart.

Stella: Make alterations, cherish the Good Stuff
Paden: gambling metaphors, "Deal me in/out", risk-aware and initially risk-averse
Mal: Justice, fairness, "That ain't right."
Cobb: business euphemisms

posts.text:
Fair enough. I'm not some kind of authority here, I'm just having fun.

But I'm intrigued by what makes a Dad Movie. Eg. why is Hunt For Red October generally agreed to be a top example? Why that one, and not some other spy movie? Hence my theory of the Dad Movie protagonist. üòÄ
posts.fullText:
Fair enough. I'm not some kind of authority here, I'm just having fun.

But I'm intrigued by what makes a Dad Movie. Eg. why is Hunt For Red October generally agreed to be a top example? Why that one, and not some other spy movie? Hence my theory of the Dad Movie protagonist. üòÄ

posts.text:
The key element of a Dad Movie is a protagonist who succeeds by being calm under pressure, providing leadership, and applying practical know-how.

MacGuyver is not in a movie, but he's a prime example of the type.

There's a large overlap with the concept of positive masculinity.
posts.fullText:
The key element of a Dad Movie is a protagonist who succeeds by being calm under pressure, providing leadership, and applying practical know-how.

MacGuyver is not in a movie, but he's a prime example of the type.

There's a large overlap with the concept of positive masculinity.

posts.text: Some of the best Dad Movies have *two* such protagonists: Heat, The Fugitive, The Shawshank Redemption, and (of course) The Hunt For Red October.
posts.fullText: Some of the best Dad Movies have *two* such protagonists: Heat, The Fugitive, The Shawshank Redemption, and (of course) The Hunt For Red October.

posts.text:
The Dad Movie protagonist does not have superhuman abilities. Star Wars, The Matrix, and Dune are enjoyed *by* Dads, but not Dad Movies. James Bond and Batman don't fit either, with their elite training and arsenals of gadgets.

But Sam Gamgee in Peter Jackson's LOTR is absolutely a Dad Movie hero.
posts.fullText:
The Dad Movie protagonist does not have superhuman abilities. Star Wars, The Matrix, and Dune are enjoyed *by* Dads, but not Dad Movies. James Bond and Batman don't fit either, with their elite training and arsenals of gadgets.

But Sam Gamgee in Peter Jackson's LOTR is absolutely a Dad Movie hero.

posts.text:
Die Hard is another Dad Movie with two main Dad characters.

John McClane, obviously, is literally a Dad who triumphs by courage and ingenuity. But Hans Gruber is a smart, capable, and respected leader -- Evil Dad, if you will. üòà

Jingle All the Way is a pretty quality dad film.

posts.text: The dad movie discourse is really just a longing for a return to craftsmanship and mid-budget bangers. I revisited Tombstone when Kilmer died and was in awe of shit we took for granted: thoughtful composition, sweeping landscapes, layered character building, competent lighting. Take me back.
posts.fullText:
The dad movie discourse is really just a longing for a return to craftsmanship and mid-budget bangers. I revisited Tombstone when Kilmer died and was in awe of shit we took for granted: thoughtful composition, sweeping landscapes, layered character building, competent lighting. Take me back.
[image alt: Doc Holliday drinking from a tin cup in Tombstone]

posts.text:
Sisu 1 isn't as much about dads. In the first movie, the standard revenge movie storyline has already happened. The soviets killed his family, and he killed over a hundred of them, retires, mines gold.

Then the movie starts, he finds gold, and some retreating nazis steal it from him.
posts.fullText:
Sisu 1 isn't as much about dads. In the first movie, the standard revenge movie storyline has already happened. The soviets killed his family, and he killed over a hundred of them, retires, mines gold.

Then the movie starts, he finds gold, and some retreating nazis steal it from him.

posts.text: Then Sisu 2. He spends some of the gold money on a gigantic truck (a very Dad move), drives to his old home, which is on land ceded to the USSR, dismantles his house and carries the wood back to Finland.  The entire Soviet army foolishly tries to stop him.
posts.fullText: Then Sisu 2. He spends some of the gold money on a gigantic truck (a very Dad move), drives to his old home, which is on land ceded to the USSR, dismantles his house and carries the wood back to Finland.  The entire Soviet army foolishly tries to stop him.

posts.text: I keep on harping on this, but watching Sisu 2, the main guy unfastens the chain that holds the lumber in in his truck, hits the brakes on his truck, and the lumber flies up, destroying an attacking fighter plane, and I thought, "That is the most dad power fantasy ever committed to film."
posts.fullText: I keep on harping on this, but watching Sisu 2, the main guy unfastens the chain that holds the lumber in in his truck, hits the brakes on his truck, and the lumber flies up, destroying an attacking fighter plane, and I thought, "That is the most dad power fantasy ever committed to film."

posts.text: My weird bit of Civil War trivia is that my father is a dead-ringer (albeit fatter) for Confederate general Joseph E Johnston. Indiana Jones and the Last Crusade: I start watching it. My brother comes downstairs "What's on?" 
"Last Crusade"
"Awesome" sits down.
Other brother wanders in "Last Crusade?"
"Yeah"
"Cool".
Dad steps in "What's on, boys?"
"Last Crusade!"
"Excellent."
Like an inescapable gravity well.

A brighter close up of me in a duffle coat, taken in a bathroom mirror.

Hey, my favorite dad movie is "Monty Python and the Holy Grail!"

My dad & I had a Saturday tradition where I would get up & we'd watch cartoons until the British comedies started on PBS, at which point we'd switch to those. :) Then we'd finish the night with SNL & Benny Hill before bed, lol.

When I was a kid we were allowed to watch pretty much any violent movie.  Jurassic Park, Goldeneye, Mission Impossible, The Rock -- I saw them all many times.  

Hunt for Red October was in our VHS library too, but I literally cannot remember watching it without my dad like I can the others.

[image alt: From action movies to high-octane thrillers, Dad Movie magic is still a huge box office draw. Although somewhat nebulous as a genre descriptor, "Dad Movies" - or films that tend to appeal to middle-aged men - tend to share certain elements or themes between them. Dadcore cinema is most synonymous with the action, war, Western, and historical drama genres, and may include a certain familial or comradely element that is endearing to the dad demographic. There is no set definition exactly - but there are certain films that give off a Dad Movie vibe, and some naturally fit that vibe better than others.

Given the broad nature of the Dad Movie umbrella, some of the greatest films of all time are in contention to be included in any list ranking the genre's greatest examples. However, this ranking is not about the best films that happen to be Dad Movies, but more a look at films that embody the Dad Movie vibe best. From Denzel Washington action thrillers to John Wayne Westerns, here are the 20 best Dad Movies of all time.]

posts.quotedText: Thinking about how I went on a run of watching Tommy Lee Jones movies after watching The Fugitive for the zillionth time. It took me on a journey. (Many were things I'd seen before but not in a while.) (God, I haven't watched any movies in like a month probably.)
quotedAltText:
Screenshot from Letterboxed:

Volcano 1997
Rewatched 12 Jun 2025
I think I enjoy all movies where Tommy Lee Jones is competent, draws on maps, and orders people around. He doesn't have to chase people (as I originally theorized, thinking many movies might be improved if you add Tommy Lee Jones chasing somebody).

I also enjoy Don Cheadle and Keith David and Anne Heche being competent here as well.

It's a ridiculous movie, but I like it anyway.

1 like

Poster for Double Jeopardy (1999)
Double Jeopardy 1999
Rewatched 10 Jun 2025
This is a ridiculous movie where you really cannot think about things very much if you want to enjoy it and sometimes that's okay. Especially if Tommy Lee Jones and Ashley Judd are involved, apparently.

Me: "That doesn't make sense."
Also me: "But look how gorgeous Ashley Judd is, it's fine."

Me: "Why would you do that?"
Also me: "Gosh, I sure like Tommy Lee Jones, I'm just gonna go with it."

Andrew Davis directed all three films. Close with Jones with a knack for ensemble casts. The small characters (local cops, MPs) are all played by the same actors.

This probably isn't what Stone intended, but that's the film he made and the effect it had.

posts.text: As history, it's garbage.  As cinema, it's goddamned brilliant and I love it.  I like Ebert's take that it's emotionally truthful...that it really reflects the suspicion and paranoia of the country after the assassination.  After all, it doesn't "feel" like one lone nutjob could have done it.
posts.fullText: As history, it's garbage.  As cinema, it's goddamned brilliant and I love it.  I like Ebert's take that it's emotionally truthful...that it really reflects the suspicion and paranoia of the country after the assassination.  After all, it doesn't "feel" like one lone nutjob could have done it.
